trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of applying perianal local anesthetics on patient comfort during visual examination of the last part of large intestine
trial_identification.scientifictitle: No effect of perianal application of topical anesthetics on patient comfort during non-sedated sigmoidoscopy: a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial

conditions.healthcondition: Patients undergoing sigmoidoscopy without any sedation

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: Patients were randomized to 3 groups according to perianal application of different topical agents 30 minutes before the procedure as follows: Group 1 - 5 mL of vaseline application (placebo) Group 2 - 5 mL of 2% lidocaine gel Group 3 - 5 ml of 2.5% lidocaine plus 2.5% prilocaine cream
interventions.comparator: Vaseline was used as lubricant in the control group

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient anxiety: assessed by STAI Iand II scales
Pain: assessed by Visual analogue Scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Just before the procedure; at the time when scope is inserted, during the procedure at intervals of 5 minutes; at the time when scope is removed, before discharge

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: ASA I-II patients undergoing sigmoidoscopy without sedation
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Exclusion criteria were use of anti-anxiety medicine within 48 hours before the procedure, cognitive dysfunction, past history of having lower endoscopy or anal/colorectal or gynecological surgery and complaint of pain at the anal area precluding examination.

trial_design.sequence: Block randomization was used to keep the sample size of the groups similar and block size was set to 3. Random Allocation Software (Ver. 1.0.0) was used to allocate the patients into groups.
